content.html:
"What's that d'ya reckon?" "What d'ya reckon's goin' on there?"

I (tried) to look up 'reckoning' and 'reckon' on the wikipedia. There's a redirect to "Counting."

My usage? d'ya reckon: an informal request for 2 cents.

cjw6k: "Who do you reckon won the vote?"
amph: "Depends who you ask."
cjw6k: "No it doesn't it depends who you asked, silly bean."

Wha'd'ya reckon?

There's a redirect to "Counting."My usage? d'ya reckon: an informal request for 2 cents.cjw6k: "Who do you reckon won the vote?"amph: "Depends who you ask."cjw6k: "No it doesn't it depends who you asked, silly bean."Wha'd'ya reckon?

I grew up with gaming and I like to make things. I like to work, a lot.

I have been writing computer programs since the unix timestamp had half the runtime it has now. ½tunix!

content.html:
Thinking back to almost four (4) years ago, when I authored the PHP extension, mf2 -still without an actual release- I now know I did a horrible, terrible, very bad thing when I placed a static copy of the test suite inside the source code and edited that copy to suit my read of the microformats 2 parsing spec. I was driven to get all the tests passing. I didn't pay any mind to how my use of the public domain test suite was less than good.

I've had a lot of time to think about this. Years. It would be easy to do something completely different, but I want to give this another try. It may yet work out for the best. Also, screw you covid-19.

I'm writing this to build momentum, as I will shortly push a commit to my mf2 repo that resets all the microformats test suite tests back to their original version. As it turns out, this is going to break my project, making ~25/~155 tests fail until I dive deep into the c code and fix them up. This is all my own doing of course! I should not have done as described with those tests, years ago.

As I work away at mf2 again and breathe some life back into the thing, I make very sure that however the test suite is used, it will be plain and obvious that my project follows the spec and the test suite. Not forks the spec, not adjusts the tests, not sits atop anything else, and definitely not makes private edits to the logic of anything I intend to republish as part of my project.

Can't put it off any longer, time to go break this thing!

I was driven to get all the tests passing. I didn't pay any mind to how my use of the public domain test suite was less than good.I've had a lot of time to think about this. Years. It would be easy to do something completely different, but I want to give this another try. It may yet work out for the best. Also, screw you covid-19.I'm writing this to build momentum, as I will shortly push a commit to my mf2 repo that resets all the microformats test suite tests back to their original version. As it turns out, this is going to break my project, making ~25/~155 tests fail until I dive deep into the c code and fix them up. This is all my own doing of course! I should not have done as described with those tests, years ago.As I work away at mf2 again and breathe some life back into the thing, I make very sure that however the test suite is used, it will be plain and obvious that my project follows the spec and the test suite. Not forks the spec, not adjusts the tests, not sits atop anything else, and definitely not makes private edits to the logic of anything I intend to republish as part of my project.Can't put it off any longer, time to go break this thing!

content.html:
I am currently at home, in the Sunbury Cove watershed of Prince Edward Island, Canada.

+
-
Tap twice quickly to enable touch
Map tiles by Stamen Design, under CC BY 3.0. Data by OpenStreetMap, under CC BY SA 3.0.
"Map Marker" icon by Stefan Parnarov, from the Noun Project, is licensed under CC BY 3.0.

The weather is a few clouds at 11.8C (53.2F) with winds in the South steady at 0.8 m/s (3 km/h; 1 mph).

The relative humidity is 97% at an air pressure of 0.999 atm (1012 mbar).

It's 3:43am ADT. The sun will rise 3 hours from now, or so.

content.html:
I set up a github workflow that uses a run step to docker build ... --target test where my multi-stage Dockerfile has the build target test in the definitions.

Github/docker determined it should build a different target, the check-build-context target and the build failed. This target is meant for use by people, not by rawboots. It's at the top of the Dockerfile where it's clear and easy to find. It's not in the hierarchy for the targeted build stage, test.

I had to move the check-build-context target below the target specified in my run step to have github/docker ignore it.

But the build succeeded! That's compatibility for all three supported versions of PHP with my extension, mf2!
content.value: I set up a github workflow that uses a run step to docker build ... --target test where my multi-stage Dockerfile has the build target test in the definitions.Github/docker determined it should build a different target, the check-build-context target and the build failed. This target is meant for use by people, not by rawboots. It's at the top of the Dockerfile where it's clear and easy to find. It's not in the hierarchy for the targeted build stage, test.I had to move the check-build-context target below the target specified in my run step to have github/docker ignore it.But the build succeeded! That's compatibility for all three supported versions of PHP with my extension, mf2!

content.html:
I now have a good CI run for mf2 in PHP-8.0. This required only changing the expected output of a couple of tests. 8.1 added some additional information into some error messages that the tests were expecting. Easy fix!

Next up is PHP-7.4 and this is going to be significantly more effort. I trashed my whole php-src checkout, since it was on the 8.1.10 tag, and I'm doing the whole thing again, but this time with 7.4.30: git clone git@github.com:php/php-src --depth 1 --branch php-7.4.30.

I'm expecting to put back some of the code I removed to get 8.1 passing CI, but as I put the code back I'll need wrap it and the code it replaces with some version checking.
content.value: I now have a good CI run for mf2 in PHP-8.0. This required only changing the expected output of a couple of tests. 8.1 added some additional information into some error messages that the tests were expecting. Easy fix!Next up is PHP-7.4 and this is going to be significantly more effort. I trashed my whole php-src checkout, since it was on the 8.1.10 tag, and I'm doing the whole thing again, but this time with 7.4.30: git clone git@github.com:php/php-src --depth 1 --branch php-7.4.30.I'm expecting to put back some of the code I removed to get 8.1 passing CI, but as I put the code back I'll need wrap it and the code it replaces with some version checking.
